instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C6905: What is C6905? Capacitor to ground on charger input, if this shorts to ground the charger will not put out any power. .
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..

threads.title: What am I missing...... apart from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
OK, <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B. No power. No Charge LED. No <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
I am using a 80w Adapter.
OK <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>
Pin 1 0.003v
Pin 2 0.001v
Pin 3 0.000v
Pin 4 0.001v
Pin 5 0.033 to 0.053v

<CAPACITOR>C6908</CAPACITOR>
Pin 1 0.089v
Pin 2 0.000v

<CAPACITOR>C6905</CAPACITOR>
Pin 1 16.60v
Pin 2 0.000v

F6905
Pin 1 16.60v
Pin 2 16.60v

<RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR>
Pin 1 0.031v
Pin 2 0.026v

<CHIP>U6901</CHIP>
Pin 1 0.024v
Pin 2 0.024v
Pin 3 0.008v
Pin 4 0.001v
Pin 5 0.021v

I have changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, I dont know why... seemed like a good idea. Basically there was a little corrosion around it and no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> at pin 12.

I have a 5.043v feed @ <SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL> on Pins 19 & 20 respectivly on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. I also have 16.6v at Pin 2 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>

Now, I am also a little confused, the 80w charger states on it 18.5v @ 4.6A and 16.5v @ 3.6A yet at the DC in board and at the fuse F6905 it is reading 16.6v yet the line states <SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> which should be 18.5v. I have used this adapter on many MBP circa 2012 and it is an original.

I know something should be producing a 3.42v feed but I am completely brain dead as to what it is. I assume its <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> but the likelyhood of having 2 duff.... maybe...

threads.title: What am I missing...... apart from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
3V42 comes out from L6995 and is not dependent of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Check resistance to ground there and post voltages for <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.
Also check resistance to ground at L7030 and post voltage at pin 3/<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: What am I missing...... apart from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I am home from work now, but will check in the morning. thanks [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] for your help, as always

threads.title: What am I missing...... apart from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
OK,
L6995
Pin 1 0.082v 19.11Kohms
Pin 2 0.074v 19.27Kohms

<CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
Pin 1 0.032v
Pin 2 0.077v
Pin 3 0.049v
Pin 4 0.064v
Pin 5 gnd
Pin 6 & 8 0.031v
Pin 7 NC

L7030
Pin 1 0.303v 12.9 Mohms
Pin 2 0.302v 14.5 Mohms

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
Pin 3 3.933v

Also, if it helps, nowhere on the board is getting warm.

Edit.... Whilst getting voltages from <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, I noticed  <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> pin 1 was grey and looked a little sad, so I removed it and replaced it with another 10uf 25v cap. I now have 2.63v at pins 6 & 8 on <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> and Pin 1 on <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>.

I am now getting the following:-
OK <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>
Pin 1 1.161v
Pin 2 0.001v
Pin 3 0.000v
Pin 4 1.154v
Pin 5 1.070 to 1.154v

<CAPACITOR>C6908</CAPACITOR>
Pin 1 1.161v
Pin 2 0.000v

<CAPACITOR>C6905</CAPACITOR>
Pin 1 16.60v
Pin 2 0.000v

F6905
Pin 1 16.60v
Pin 2 16.60v

<RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR>
Pin 1 1.154v
Pin 2 1.151v

<CHIP>U6901</CHIP>
Pin 1 1.114v
Pin 2 1.115v
Pin 3 0.000v
Pin 4 1.162v
Pin 5 1.154v

Retested
L6995
Pin 1 1.165v 18.70Kohms
Pin 2 1.164v 18.74Kohms

<CHIP>U6990</CHIP>
Pin 1 0.558v
Pin 2 1.164v
Pin 3 1.170v
Pin 4 1.165v
Pin 5 gnd
Pin 6 & 8 2.170v
Pin 7 NC

L7030
Pin 1 1.171v 4.113 kohms
Pin 2 1.171v starts at 2.72Mohms and drops

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
Pin 3 3.933v

threads.title: What am I missing...... apart from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> is burnt.
Check for short on pins 6 & 8 of <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> before change it.

For the future, measure resistance to ground on diode mode, red probe to ground; unless we specify ohm scale...
And you don't need to measure on both sides of a coil!!!

threads.title: What am I missing...... apart from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Sorry, thouhgt I had meter on diode...
Pins 6&8 when tested with red on gnd and black on either pin or pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> or the probe point in between I get a quick beep and OL on the meter. I have gone around the other pins in diode mode with the black on pin 8 and touched the others with OL all around except pin 6 which as I expect no resistance and continual beep. 

Tested <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> and it shows no short to ground ( dont know why I did that, i think i like to hear a beep :) ). Resistance is 1.707 kohms . I do not have a 1 ohm resisitor to hand ( 1r0) but I have got a 1ohm ( 10Y) which going by my mate google should be OK, just slightly smaller. It reads 1.1 ohm, will this be OK?

threads.title: What am I missing...... apart from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
It should work.
Please provide accurate information for the future.
Be patient when check diode mode in the mobo, if your DMM has also buzzer on the same scale.
It will shortly beep when charges a capacitor!

threads.title: What am I missing...... apart from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thank you [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] . I did try to provide as much as I could. I didnt realise at the time I was in resistance, I will make sure that I am in the right mode, should the need arise again. I will be back in work on Monday so I will update you then on the progress.

threads.title: What am I missing...... apart from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: hi [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] , that worked a treat. all up and running, thank you very much and Happy new year.
